courseTitle: Exploring Chemical and Physical Changes (Dry Lab)

pageData.text: In this investigation, students will view a series of laboratory activities that feature <button class='glossary-text'>physical</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>chemical changes</button>, and explore the differences in these changes. They’ll identify the types of changes that occur based on defined criteria and consider the observations that lead to these conclusions.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text: Computer with internet access

Activity 5: Copper(II) Sulfate and Sodium Hydroxide - 5 minutes

Activity 8: Copper(II) Sulfate/Sodium Chloride and Aluminum Metal - 5 minutes 
Activity 9: Iron Metal and Copper(II) Sulfate - 5 minutes

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Differentiate between <button class='glossary-text'>chemical</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>physical changes</button>.
Describe features that identify changes as chemical or physical.
List examples of physical and chemical changes, then classify why these are chemical or physical changes.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.desc: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Knowing whether something will undergo a or is important when a scientist wants to preserve an item. One example of this is forensic examinations of priceless works of art. Researchers closely examined Leonardo da Vinci’s Portrait of a Lady with an Ermine and found an entire fingerprint in the shadowing effect given to the lady’s necklace. They were able to match this print to two others found in his works and confirmed they belonged to da Vinci. From these fingerprints, researchers were able to learn more about da Vinci all while preserving his artwork.One of the oldest methods for developing fingerprints is the iodine fuming method, which takes advantage of physical changes. When iodine crystals are warmed, they produce iodine vapor via a physical change called sublimation. The object in question is exposed to these fumes, which are adsorbed on the sebaceous material that is typically found in fingerprints. This interaction leaves a brown latent print that fades as soon as the object is removed from the presence of the iodine fumes.

pageData.desc: A fingerprint illustration over a background with curls of chemical fumes.
pageData.altText: A fingerprint illustration over a background with curls of chemical fumes.

pageData.text: Some changes are so much a part of daily life that they are hardly noticed. Paints are mixed; ingredients become meals; tools rust; fuels are consumed; and rain and snow form, fall, and then seem to disappear. Some of these changes are physical, and some are chemical.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>A <button class='glossary-text'>physical change</button> may be associated with a change in the appearance of a substance but not in its chemical composition. In other words, the original reactant molecules have not been changed into different molecules in the product. For example, a change in state is a physical change. Solid ice and liquid water have the same chemical composition (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O), but the state (solid vs. liquid) of the H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O is physically different.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a physical change?

options.text: burning a piece of paper
wetting a piece of paper with water
folding a piece of paper
coloring a piece of paper with a red marker
ripping a piece of paper into 4 pieces

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Burning paper represents a combustion reaction, which transforms the large carbohydrates in paper into smaller carbon dioxide and water molecules.

pageData.question: Which is the best example of a physical change?

options.text: boiling water
synthesizing water from hydrogen and oxygen
rust forming on an iron surface
metabolizing water in your body
burning a candle

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. A state change, such as heating water from a liquid to a gas, is an example of the physical appearance of water changing without its chemical composition (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O) being altered.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change. If not, then it is a physical change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Physical changes are often associated with changes in appearance but not in the chemical composition of the substance. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change. If not, then it is a physical change.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Chemical changes</button> result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds. Atoms of compounds are rearranged to form product substances that differ from the original reactant substances. A chemical change can be depicted by an equation showing the rearrangement of atoms. Even when the identities of the substances are unknown, some conspicuous indicators suggest a chemical change:

text: Production of a precipitate, an insoluble solid that emerges from a liquid solution
A color change that cannot be explained by a simple combination of colors (e.g., two colorless chemicals that form a yellow compound when mixed)

pageData.text: These indicators simply suggest the likelihood that a change is chemical; <button class='glossary-text'>physical changes</button> sometimes produce these effects as well.

pageData.question: Which of these describes a chemical change?

options.text: A change resulting from the rearrangement of chemical bonds.
A change in the appearance of a substance.
A change that always produces a solid product.
A change in the quantity of matter.
A purple color-change as red and blue substances are mixed.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a chemical change?

options.text: rubbing alcohol evaporates leaving an empty beaker
plants produce sugar from carbon dioxide gas
two colorless chemicals mix to form a pink solution
two chemicals are mixed, and the solution becomes warm
two liquids are mixed, and a white solid forms

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The evaporation of a liquid, such as rubbing alcohol, represents a state change from liquid to gas, which is a physical change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Chemical changes result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds. Ask yourself if you are changing the chemical composition of the substance before and after the change.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a chemical change?

options.text: the flame on the wick of a candle
ice melting in the sun
breaking a stick in half
frozen carbon dioxide (CO2) forming a cloud of (CO2) gas and water vapor
water boiling on the stove

assestmentData.question: Which of the following indicators is LEAST likely to suggest a chemical change has taken place?

options.text: a solid becoming liquid
production of a gas
production of heat
two colorless liquids forming a colored solution
production of a precipitate

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a physical change?

options.text: water forming ice crystals on the window in winter
the bubbles formed when vinegar and baking soda are mixed
a pot roast cooking in the oven
food scraps turning to compost in the compost bin
the creation of plastic from petroleum

assestmentData.question: Breads can be described by their leavening (rising) agent: yeast breads rely on bubbles of carbon dioxide (CO2) produced as yeast cells digest carbohydrates in the dough; quick breads rely on bubbles of CO2 produced as baking soda and acid are added to the dough; flat breads rely on bubbles formed by the rapid evaporation of water from the dough as it is exposed to high heat. Which bread type(s) rely on chemical changes to rise?

options.text: yeast breads and quick breads
quick breads and flat breads
yeast breads and flat breads
yeast breads only
flat breads only

data.title: Chemical change
data.content: Result from the formation, breakage, or rearrangement of chemical bonds.

data.title: Physical change
data.content: May be associated with a change in the appearance, but not in the chemical composition, of a substance.
